Entries.default: The man sitting here nurses a mug of grog. From the slightly glassy look of his eyes, it's not his first serving. He seems entirely absorbed in a coin that he juggles along the ribbed line of his knuckles.
"Aye." He inhales deeply and releases a great sigh.
"I only survived on account of this coin. Cannons firing, folks shouting and screaming, and I see this at my feet, shiny as you please. Decide, for Wael knows what reason to pick it up."
"That sets the coin to rolling, though, and I chase after it. Deck behind me explodes to splinters, all shot to shit, and me not there only on account of this coin."

"Wake up down the way at Vilario's Rest, nothing but the clothes on my back and this coin clutched tight in my grip. Come up here looking for work, for a ship to get me off of this backwater island."

He takes a long swig from his mug.
"It's not your fault, you know. Blame the pirates. Or your captain for fighting."
[Pretend to drink.]
[Poison his drink with fungal bile.]
[Leave.] "Thank you for sharing."
"Maybe you ain't wrong. Maybe I'm no soul-weak coward, just a sad, fortune-favored bastard."
The man drinks eagerly. Given that he was half-sodden when you found him, it doesn't take long before he rests his head in his hands with an incoherent mumble. Moments later, he begins to snore.

The man doesn't last long after he quaffs the drink. He seizes up, falls from his chair, and twitches on the ground, blood foaming from his mouth and nostrils.

Wide eyes around the tavern watch as the man goes still. The coin rests on the table, forgotten.

"Were there something else you wanted, Watcher? I've got friends to forget."

The man doesn't look up from his mug.
"Thanks for the words, Watcher. Really helped set things in perspective and all."
"No, Thorel... pants are not... for your head..."
"Was it worth it? All that, for this little thing..."
"Nice coin."
"Mind if I join you?"
"Buy you a drink?"
[Sit down across from him.]
The man blinks up at you. It takes him a few seconds to focus on your features.

"Aye, I'll have a drink. If you're having one yourself."

He gestures at the seat opposite. When you raise your hand to the barkeep, he finishes the mug he'd been working at in one long swallow.
The man blinks up at you. It takes him a few seconds to focus on your features.

"Thanks."

He frowns down at the coin.
The man blinks up at you. It takes him a few seconds to focus on your features.

"Ain't nobody stopping you."

He gestures at the seat opposite.
The man blinks up at you. It takes him a few seconds to focus on your features.
"Something I can do for you, Watcher?"
"You're cradling that coin like it has a story to tell."
"I've come for the coin."
[Leave] "I was just going, actually."
"Suit yourself." He shrugs and returns his attention to his drink.
"I take it you've heard of me."
"You weren't exactly quiet when you came through here the first time."
"Sorry, mate. Ain't available for the taking."
"Any reason why?"

"Though it's certainly been quieter since you left."

He glances askance at Xoti.
"Yeah, well, if folks had listened to me then - might be not so many would've died. I think it was worth shouting about, thank you."
"I were on a ship out of Telaneir. We traded in luxuries... spirits mostly. "
"Aye, lad. A right sordid collection of shits, that crew, and the High Queen Sea-Devil of the Deadfire the biggest shit of them all."
"Go on."
"You're going to get around to this coin at some point, right?"
"Ship came up on us out of the fog, flying the thrice-fucked flag of the Pr√≠ncipi sen Patrena. A dhow by the name of Misery's Delight, if you know it."
"We certainly knew it, and of Malnaj's reputation. Yet the captain set to fight her off, damned fool that he was."
"You have to defend what's yours."

"I... suppose..."

He frowns into his ale.
"And a cannonball tears through the deck right above me - right where my head'd just been."

"It rolls through the rail posts, and I - not willing to let this damned thing be - leap after it. Feel my fingers close around it right as the ship goes up behind me in a great fucking fireball worthy of Magran herself. They must've hit the powder kegs."
"You don't sound very happy about it."

"Probably 'cause I ain't. Lot of good people died that day, men and women I liked and respected. And me, here, alive and sodden in Port Maje, all on account of taking a shine to a piece of silver."

He sighs again, long and tired.
[Purchase rum.] "This calls for something stronger. Let's drink to their memory."
"Wouldn't be a mariner if I turned down a drink of rum... or pour out a dram for the lads."
[Drink like a normal person.]
"Can I buy the coin off of you?"
"I wish I could, but there's no amount of coin I consider worth the fortune this little piece of silver has brought me."
"It ain't for sale, Watcher."
"Aye. Thank you for the drink."
"Aye. Safe sailing, Watcher."

"Take this, then. May it bring you better luck than it's brought me."

He passes the coin to you.
"You think the coin's a blessing, but it's a curse. It's not that you lived. It's that everyone else died."

"That... that makes a strange kind of sense, don't it? And you seem the sort to know your hexes from your curses."

His nose wrinkles as he peers down at the coin.
[Drink him under the table.]
"To the crew of the Untold Fortune." He throws back a dram, and quickly follows it with a second.
"Maybe you ain't wrong. Maybe I'm no soul-weak coward, just a sad, fortune-favored bastard."
Apparently the sailor, despite having a head start, handles his spirits better than you do...
[Take the coin.]
[Leave it be.]
Coin in hand, you leave the mariner asleep in his chair.

"Brought mead - wyrthoneg for the Dawnstars - and ynefer out. Returned with rum and arrack, but also murkberries and khapa leaves."
"Would it make you feel better to know that Malnaj is dead?"
"A bit, aye."
"Certainly improved my spirits."
"It's not your fault, you know. Blame the pirates. Or your captain for fighting."

"Only one way to know for certain."

He taps the tarnished coin.
